Searching values
You have two options.
Value search
This lets you search for values that meet the specified filters. You can use a combination of filters to achieve better results.
The --read option matches values in readable memory.
The --write option matches values in writable memory.
The --execute option matches values in writable memory.
The --eq option matches values that equal to the given value.
The --ne option matches values that do not equal to the given value.
The --gt option matches values that are greater than the given value.
The --gte option matches values that are greater than or equal the given value.
The --lt option matches values that are lesser than the given value.
The --lte option matches values that are lesser than or equal the given value.
If you pass the --input option, the command will expect as input the output of a previous search result and that will allow you to specify filters that compare the old value with the new one.
The --inc option matches values that were incremented by the given value.
The --inc-up-to option matches values that were incremented up to the given value.
The --dec option matches values that were decremented by the given value.
The --dec-up-to option matches values that were decremented up to the given value.
The --changed option matches values that have changed.
The --unchanged option matches values that have not changed.
The --increased option matches values that increased.
The --decreased option matches values that decreased.
The command accepts type options. You can find out all about them here.
Here's how you would find all 32-bit integers greater than 0 and less than or equal to 100 in a program whose PID is 12345.
$ proctal search --pid=12345 --type=integer --integer-size=32 --gt=e0 --lte=100
And here's how you would search for all the values that increased after a previous search.
$ proctal search --pid=12345 --type=integer --integer-size=32 --gt=e0 --lte=100 > search-1 $ proctal search --pid=12345 --type=integer --integer-size=32 --increased --input < search-1
Pattern matching
For when you want to find a sequence of bytes that match a given pattern.
Here's how you would search for potential function calls in x86:
$ proctal pattern --pid=12345 --program-code 'E8 ?? ?? ?? ??'
The --read option matches values in readable memory.
The --write option matches values in writable memory.
The --execute option matches values in writable memory.
The --program-code option matches values in the program's code.
